Welcome to /k/, 4chan's weapons board. Our board centers around weapons, armor, and other myriad military technology. Before posting a thread, please check our catalog to ensure that a thread about the same topic does not already exist.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
To have an effective military force, you need:

>Discipline and accountability (especially self-disciple)
Many people in prison are there because they are unable to control their behavior, and addictions. They're also often bad at submitting to authority or being accountable for their actions. You're starting from the worst place socially to find people.

> Loyalty
You can't have a fighting force with a priority (escaping, switching sides, committing crimes, running away, staying alive, etc..) that is different than the stated purpose of the mission/war. Otherwise you will be working at cross purposes and wasting resources (guns, fuel, bullets, food, uniforms, leaders) for no gain.

>Training:
They're prisoners. Not trained soldiers.

> Unit Cohesion and High Morale
To fight effectively, you need troops to trust one another and work together for a common purpose. People convicted of murder, rape, etc.. that are being used by Russia are unlikely to trust one another or be worthy of trust. Their leaders are unlikely to care about their wellbeing or the careful the careful stewardship of their lives. Morale an unit cohesion will be poor.

>Intellect
If they're anything like western prisoners, they're highly likely to be low-IQ and unable to accomplish the tasks set out for them. Look at what happened with McNamara's Morons. Even with training, good cohesion, morale, loyalty, etc.. they were still poor soldiers.

Russia is using scarce resources on penal battalions that will likely be a net drain on resources. It just shows how fucking stupid they are more than anything.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
Previous >>56139887
End of Black Friday deals edition

Resource on what these spec terminology mean
https://www.nite-walker.com/post/2019/11/21/specs-for-dummies-101
https://apollogearco.com/blogs/news/night-vision-specs-explained
https://gloomgroup.com/blogs/night-vision-info/night-vision-specifications-understanding-what-they-mean

You shouldn't be chasing for spec values but they do exist and if you wanted to know what "better spec" values are there's a way to know which unit is desirable over another.
Most retailers won't post this info as they build NVDs to order, first come first serve, and depending on their grading scale of high, mid, low tier it may differ from retailers. If a retailer offer a “ready to ship” fully built units they will list the spec values. Hand select is an option from retailers that will try to match to your spec requirements.

Some reputable retailers:
https://www.jrhenterprises.com/
https://nvisionoptics.com/
https://www.customnightvision.com/
https://gooningear.com/
https://apollogearco.com
https://blackphasetactical.com/
https://steeleindustries.com/

SNR: signal to noise ratio, the amount of signal the tube can make compared to the noise
EBI: equivalent background information, how much false image appears in the screen through which the actual image has to show, sort of a noise floor of sorts
Halo: How big the circle of bloom is around lights
Photocathode Sensitivity: How sensitive the photocathode is
LP Resolution: Line pair res of the center of the image as measure against a standardized chart

If one spec is shit it negates the rest, if you have a halo of 2.0 it kinda fucks on an EBI of 0.20 if you want to do any kind of shooting and it's all a balance game

The numbers to meet or beat are
EBI under 1, preferably under 0.6 being great, 0.1 is gucci
Halo under 1, anything under 0.7 is awesome
SNR, over 25 anything over 30 is gucci
Photocathode, 1900+ is pretty great, 2500+ is stellar
Resolution of 64+ is good, 72+ is gucci

threads.sub: /k/ approved literatur regarding warfare: Storm of Steel, post moar
threads.com:
I will start: Storm of Steel (in German: In Stahlgewittern, lit.'In Steel Thunderstorms'; original English title: In Storms of Steel) is the memoir of German officer Ernst Jünger's experiences on the Western Front during the First World War from December 1914 to August 1918.

> The book is a graphic account of trench warfare. It was largely devoid of editorialization when first published, but was heavily revised several times. The book established Jünger's fame as a writer in the 1920s. The judgment of contemporaries and later critics reflects the ambivalence of the work, which describes the war in all its brutality, but neither expressly condemns it nor goes into its political causes. It can be read affirmatively, neutrally or as an anti-war book.

Why I recommend it: Its accurately describes how the war actually was, all the details. Very very good read.

Why would NATO join the war? All we have to do is literally sit back and send our 2nd rate equipment to Ukraine and Ukraine is destroying Russia for us. Nukes are certainly one of the reasons why NATO doesn't fully intervene, but the main reason is we just don't need to. It's a lot harder to justify full scale military interventions in Western countries, a consequence of belonging to Democratic societies, as unless the entire nation is onboard with such actions, it can lead to massive repercussions for the current ruling administration of that country. There's a lot more emphasis put on human lives in the West, and even one soldier dying is seen as a tragedy. But imagine if NATO sent in actual soldiers, battlegroups & frontline equipment to Ukraine; Russia would be cleared out in weeks. In 9 months, Ukraine went from nearly 40% of their country occupied/under siege by the Russians to more around 10% and with that number decreasing nearly every week. And they're on track to GAIN territory with likely retaking Crimea.

The threat of nukes or not, the moment Russia actually USES nukes, even on Ukraine, means a full scale intervention of all of NATO + even China fully cutting off Russia. The moment someone uses nukes means the moment that nuclear deterrence no longer works and thus the only reaction to such an event is to immediately stamp out the one who uses them before they can use them again.

If you are in a situation where fast reloads are important then that implies a combat situation. If you're in a combat situation, why are you dicking around with pistol cartridges at all, when you could be carrying intermediates?

Meanwhile a levergun has an advantage the semiauto doesnt: it cycles everything under the sun without worry about the pressure curve of the ammo, including shorter/weaker cartridges, like firing .38spl in a .357 magnum levergat.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>56178015
rimlock isn't the only issue with revolver carts and the deagle. Not all loads will cycle the action on the deagle. Since it's gas-operated there must be some minimum amount of pressure in the barrel when the bullet passes the gas port. That part of the pressure curve is not a design consideration for revolver ammo, so some loads work and some loads don't. That problem doesn't exist in firing revolver carts in manual-action guns, or shooting the Deagle in calibers specifically designed for it (.50 AE, .440 Cor-bon, .429 DE)

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
having bought a couple of old collectible firearms I've noticed a pattern: people tend to take great care of the outside, but on the inside there are pockets that never, ever get any attention and those will very slowly rust.

here's the magazine tube of a Winchester Model 71 deluxe. outside finish is like new. inside is 99%. magazine tube? probably not unscrewed since it was screwed in by the factory. it's not even complicated, just remove some screws (with a proper gun screwdriver kit!) once cleaned up it will look almost new, but the oil I'm using for cleaning (brunox turbo spray) wiping of reddish-brown tells me what I'm doing now should have been done decades ago.

disassemble your firearms. every surface made of steel (even stainless), especially those you never see when it's assembled, needs a protective coating or it will inevitably rust. those screws holding buttplate and sling swivel in the stock are rusting right now, unless you conserved them. the factory sure didn't.

I use calcium sulfonate grease for the inside and renaissance wax for the outside/stock parts. it's one of those things you do once right. don't be the guy with rusty threads.

last_replies.com:
>>56174682
>>56174519
Because the expensive, bespoke guns like Holland & Holland or Purdy do indeed have those types of engravings, as do things like the Beretta Silver Pigeon series. However the typical American consoomer will not buy them. They can't afford to buy them. Even a Silver Pigeon, at $2000, is far beyond what most are willing to pay for a shotgun when they can get their justasgood maverick 88 for about 1/10th of that.

Tldr the people who DO buy that stuff are rich people, and generally you'll find it from European sporting companies... the same companies that have historically targeted the richer class, who could afford hunting. The American gun culture is radically different from European gun culture in its origins that way. For much of western europe it wasn't about frontiers or even protection really--it was about being a rich guy riding on a horse and wing-blasting deer so your dogs could chase it as it bled out. Or it was about extreme focus on like, 1 bullet for mega accuracy. In contrast American gun culture was far more stripped of pomp and circumstance--it was utilitarian because "scalped by Comanche" was a thing that could happen, because "I am moving 1000 miles from the coast into the great plains" was a thing, because "Holy shit it's freezing and there's no food, I must find a buffalo to kill" was a way of life, and because "raided by Mexican desperados" was a thing.

Our gun culture wasn't ornamental unless you were rich. In that case things didn't change. Ours was always rooted in basic utilitarianism and ultimately mass production. The ethos of Taurus is far closer to the American gun culture ethos than something like a Laugo Alien is. Cheap. Plain. Found everywhere.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>56174519
>>56178138
>Why is everyone so stuck on the guns are tools thing? Sure they are, and function comes before form, but they don't have to be mostly spartan, with a few exceptions.
I don't agree this is a culture thing or think people are "stuck on" it, it's just a reality of mass manufacturing. Decorations means less when there are 100000 others completely identical. And on the flipside, the more artistic and stylistic the decorations, the more likely it is to only have niche appeal, which then greatly increases cost per unit and raises manufacturer/retailer risk (have inventory sitting around unsold longer). Yet we still see guns designed with aesthetics in mind all the time, and people do do stuff like custom color jobs or furniture at least. There is a desire for cool stuff, but same as the entire rest of modern society it's not necessarily that compatible with current industrial practice.

I think advancing technology will eventually give us back what was once taken. As stuff like 3D printing continues to improve and drop in cost, eventually it may become a more common service to get smaller more custom runs of stuff that still can hit close to mass manufactured pricing. We see lots of creativity happening already in 3D printed receivers even with current tech. The last 150 years may ultimately come to be seen as something of a blip in history.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.sub: How the fuck do you recce?
threads.com:
Reading on this stuff that is available on the surface the general idea that I infer is:
1. Do forward patrols to locate enemy positions, pretty straightforward. Tactical level.
2. Take and interrogate prisoners, again pretty straightforward. From what I understand this was doctrinally how soviets got their intel. Tactical and operational level of intel.
3. Conduct aggresive probing attacks, "fighting for information". Operational level of intel (ie. adversary's strength and disposition)
4. Deploying suicidal recce screen comprised of light vehicles whose main purpose is to draw fire. Doctrinally how large scale maneuvers of soviet armored formation is done (which we see in action in form of suicidal recce runs early in the war by Russia, and to a lesser extent Ukraine), also kinda how NATO done it (minus the suicidal part I guess?)

From watching videos of Ukrainian patrols 1 in itself is already confusing with recon is mostly guys locating (temporarily?) abandoned forward russian positions. Not exactly how I pictured how a patrol work; which I imagine involved more stealth or aggresiveness rather than people just casually driving cars and walking around casually. Also, how the fuck info you got from such mission remains relevant; wouldn't the adversary relocate their stuff when its apparent they've been recce'd?
3 as I understand is pretty much exemplified in gun runs in Iraq and Kharkov. I guess the intel is pretty much "whats the heaviest shit they can throw at us here" kind of thing. 4 I just found completely brazen and can't wrap my mind on. Those soviet reconaisance cars are pretty much expendable tin coffins in operational planning. Sending some of your most well trained men into certain death to screen for your more "valuable" assets (aka. tanks) just doesn't make sense to me. I'm sure I got a lot of things wrong so feel free to correct me.
